DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation._A group of nearly parallel rays of electromagnetic radiation or a stream of particles._Emission or propagation of electromagnetic energy (waves/rays), or the waves/rays themselves; a stream of electromagnetic particles (electrons, neutrons, protons, alpha particles) or a mixture of these. The most common source is the sun._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

Concepts.definition: Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.
A group of nearly parallel rays of electromagnetic radiation or a stream of particles.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: CS: A string of characters with leading or trailing spaces being non-significant consisting of Upper Case, 0-9, SPACE, Underscore. [Standard-based]_Emission or propagation of electromagnetic energy (waves/rays), or the waves/rays themselves; a stream of electromagnetic particles (electrons, neutrons, protons, alpha particles) or a mixture of these. The most common source is the sun._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stable elementary particles having the smallest known negative charge, present in all elements; also called negatrons. Positively charged electrons are called positrons. The numbers, energies and arrangement of electrons around atomic nuclei determine the chemical identities of elements. Beams of electrons are called CATHODE RAYS or BETA RAYS, the latter being a high-energy biproduct of nuclear decay.

Concepts.definition: A fundamental particle with a negative charge.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An elementary particle with 0 charge and a mass about equal to that of a proton.

Concepts.definition: An elementary particle with 0 charge and a mass about equal to that of a proton.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A single unit of electromagnetic radiation, generally considered to be a discrete particle having no mass or charge.

Concepts.definition: A single unit of electromagnetic radiation, generally considered to be a discrete particle having no mass or charge.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A small, positively charged particle of matter found in the atoms of all elements.  Streams of protons generated by special equipment can be used for radiation treatment.

Concepts.definition: A fundamental particle with a positive charge.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An advanced form of 3-Dimensional Conformal Radiation Therapy that involves the use of varying intensities of small radiation beams to produce dosage distributions that are more precise than those possible with 3-D CRT.

Concepts.definition: An advanced form of 3-Dimensional Conformal Radiation Therapy (3D CRT) that involves the use of varying intensities of small radiation beams to produce dosage distributions that are more precise than those possible with 3D CRT.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stereotactic radiation therapy in which one or several maximum dose radiation treatments are delivered targeting cancers of the body, excluding the brain or spine.

Concepts.definition: Stereotactic radiation therapy in which one or several maximum dose radiation treatments are delivered targeting cancers of the body, excluding the brain or spine.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ReferenceDocuments.name: DICOM Condition
ReferenceDocuments.description: Required if treatment technique requires a dose that would normally require overriding of treatment machine safety controls.
